description: Move you camera until white dots will display in your screen. Touch at any white dots to start your learning!
Hello everyone! Today, we're diving into the amazing world of microscopes!
These incredible tools allow us to see things invisible to the naked eye,
acting like our windows into the tiny world. From studying cells to analyzing
materials, microscopes are essential scientific instruments.
Let's start with the foundation the base. Imagine it as the
strong legs holding everything up for steady observations. It's usually made of
metal or plastic and has rubber feet to prevent slipping. Some
even have compartments for storing microscope accessories.
Now, for the remaining parts of the microscope, you can see them in the table.
Drag them into the base just like how you build puzzles so that we can build the microscope.
For each part that you drag, we will see if your answer is correct. Your right and wrong answers are
recorded, so be careful! I will also explain each part if you place the correct part.
Remember, there's an order in building them just like in puzzles! Good luck!
Arm connecting the base and the head is the arm It's like a bridge that allows us to adjust the microscope's position comfortably.
To get clear views, use the focus knob on the arm to move the objective lenses up and down, sharpening the image.
The lamp, like a dimmer switch, lets us control the amount of light passing through the specimen.
The tray is the platform where specimens on slides are placed, holding them steady for examination.
The slide holder secures the slides on the stage, ensuring they stay stable while we view them.
The condenser, located beneath the stage, focuses light onto the specimen like a spotlight. It allows us to adjust the intensity and angle of light, enhancing contrast and sharpness.
Lenses! These lenses vary in magnification powers, such as 4x, 8x, 40x, and 100x. Higher magnification allows us to zoom in on the smallest details.
Finally, we have the ocular lens, located at the top of the microscope closest to your eye. This lens acts like a magnifying glass, further enhancing the image produced by the objective lens.
By understanding each of these microscope parts and how they work
together, we can unlock the mysteries of the microscopic world.
That's a wrap, Good job guys! See you on next lesson
